question: Sometimes you think "I need to do this" but still can't get yourself to start studying.
explanation: Not being able to start isn't "laziness" - one view is that it's a natural response of avoiding discomfort. First, it's OK not to blame yourself for not being able to start.

best_for: People who can't get started studying
People who tend to blame themselves for procrastination
limitations: Chronic lack of motivation may require a different approach
expanded_details.citation_role: Supports the emotion regulation model of procrastination through observational research

question: If you wait thinking "I'll start when I feel motivated," what tends to happen?
choices: Motivation doesn't come and time just passes
Motivation naturally wells up
You feel relaxed and become more efficient
explanation: Research suggests that motivation is less about "waiting for it" and more about "it comes once you start." This is called behavioral activation. ("Naturally welling up" and "relaxation boosting efficiency" are rare. Waiting usually doesn't work.)

best_for: People who spend a long time waiting for motivation
People who struggle to get started
limitations: When genuinely exhausted, rest is necessary
expanded_details.citation_role: Explains behavioral activation theory in procrastination research

question: Which method has been reported as effective for lowering the barrier to start studying?
choices: Decide to open your materials "for just 10 seconds"
Set up the perfect environment for long focus sessions
Wait until you feel motivated
explanation: Even just 10 seconds of "starting" tends to make it easier to switch into the task. It's OK if you stop after 10 seconds. If it doesn't work, try something else. Just try once. ("Setting up the perfect environment" and "waiting for motivation" take too much time.)
actionable_advice: 💡 Next time you can't start studying, try "opening your materials for just 10 seconds."

best_for: People who struggle to get started
limitations: When genuinely exhausted, rest is necessary
If you can't move even for 10 seconds, don't force it
expanded_details.citation_role: Indirectly supports the effectiveness of the 10-second rule from procrastination research
expanded_details.try_this: Try "opening your materials for just 10 seconds"

tiny_metric.before_prompt: How much do you "not want to do it" right now? (0-10)
tiny_metric.stop_rule: If it stays the same or goes up, call it a day

question: Deciding in advance "When X happens, I'll do Y" tends to increase follow-through rates.
explanation: This is called "implementation intention" or "If-Then planning." For example: "After dinner, I sit down at my desk." Research reports that follow-through rates tend to be higher compared to having no plan.

best_for: People who make plans but can't follow through
People who want to build habits
limitations: Less effective when the trigger is vague
expanded_details.citation_role: Research directly testing the effectiveness of implementation intentions (If-Then planning)

question: When you can't get started studying, which describes you best?
choices: I don't know where to begin
It feels too bothersome to move
I freeze up trying to do it perfectly
No particular pattern
explanation: All answers are valid. Noticing your own pattern tends to make it easier to choose the right strategy.

question: When using If-Then planning, which format is easiest to follow through on?
choices: Decide using the format: "When [trigger], I will [action]"
Resolve to "try harder"
Think "I'll study someday"
explanation: Pairing a trigger (when/where) with an action (what to do) tends to make execution more automatic. Just try once. ("Try harder" and "someday" are too vague and unlikely to lead to action.)
actionable_advice: 💡 Set one If-Then for today: "When [trigger], I'll open my materials for just 10 seconds"

best_for: People whose plans tend to fall through
People who want to build habits
limitations: Less effective if the trigger isn't part of daily routine
expanded_details.citation_role: Indirectly supports the specific format of implementation intentions
expanded_details.try_this: Set one: "When [trigger], I'll open my materials for just 10 seconds"

tiny_metric.before_prompt: Did you follow through on your If-Then this week?
tiny_metric.after_prompt: How many times did you follow through?
tiny_metric.success_rule: Even once a week is a win
tiny_metric.stop_rule: If you can't follow through for 2 weeks, try a different method

comparator.cost: 30 seconds to plan / 10 seconds to execute

fallback.next: Use "when I feel like checking my phone" as the trigger

question: There's a view that procrastination on studying isn't just about "weak willpower."
explanation: Research reports that procrastination is more often caused by "avoidance of discomfort" and "task ambiguity" than by willpower. Addressing it through systems tends to work better than blaming yourself.

best_for: People who tend to blame themselves
People who rely too much on willpower
limitations: Not all procrastination has the same cause
expanded_details.citation_role: Supports the emotion regulation model of procrastination

question: To reduce "environmental friction" for starting to study, which approach is easiest?
choices: Leave your materials open on your desk
Set up the perfect environment before starting
Wait until you feel motivated
explanation: The less effort it takes to start, the more likely you are to take action. Leaving materials open on your desk can lower the barrier to getting started. Just try once. ("Perfect environment" and "waiting for motivation" tend to lead to procrastination.)
actionable_advice: 💡 Before bed tonight, leave tomorrow's study materials open on your desk.

best_for: People who struggle to get started
People who spend too much time setting up the environment
limitations: May backfire in a cluttered environment
expanded_details.citation_role: Indirectly supports the link between environmental friction and action initiation
expanded_details.try_this: 👉 Before studying → open your materials and place them on your desk for just 10 seconds

tiny_metric.before_prompt: Were the materials open in the morning?
tiny_metric.after_prompt: If they were open, did you start studying?
tiny_metric.success_rule: Starting with materials already open counts as a win
tiny_metric.stop_rule: If no effect after one week, stop

fallback.when: No space to leave materials out
fallback.next: Put the study app on your phone's home screen

question: Which technique from today's lesson could you use starting tomorrow?
choices: "Open my materials for just 10 seconds"
Plan ahead with "If-Then planning"
"Leave materials open on desk" environment design
Try all of them
explanation: All of them are worth trying. If one doesn't work, try another. That's learning too. Just try once. ("All of them" is fine, but no need to push it - start with just one.)
actionable_advice: 💡 Try just once tomorrow: when you can't start studying, "open your materials for just 10 seconds."

best_for: People who want to start new habits
expanded_details.try_this: Use "open your materials for just 10 seconds" once tomorrow

tiny_metric.metric: Did you use it at least once this week?
tiny_metric.stop_rule: If you didn't use it for a week, drop it

comparator.baseline: Not trying anything and continuing to procrastinate

fallback.next: Shrink the task to the minimum (e.g., solve just one problem)

question: Did the "how to start studying" techniques in this lesson seem useful to you?
choices: Seems useful
Might not be a great fit
Not sure yet
explanation: All answers are valid. If it "might not be a great fit," it's also important to look for a different approach. The causes of procrastination differ from person to person, so the process of finding what works for you is itself valuable.
